blog.title: Pretend I’m Something Better.
blog.description: 24, California, Female, Film Student. Desperately in love with movies and the people that make them happen. Mostly Marvel, but you know.

summary: you know what’s really been bugging me... At the end of Endgame when Sam is talking to old Cap Sam asks him “So did something go...
body:
you know what’s really been bugging me… At the end of Endgame when Sam is talking to old Cap Sam asks him “So did something go really wrong or really right?” And Cap answers by saying “Well, after I put the stones back, I figured I should try some of that life Tony was always telling me to get…”

Why doesn’t he say “Nat” there? It would have been such a nice moment and would have made so much sense. Nat spent the entirety of CAWS trying to set him up on dates. Earlier in Endgame they swap this EXACT line. When they’re at Avengers HQ right before the answer Scott’s call Steve says “I think we both need to get a life.” And one of the last conversations Steve has before he goes back is with Bruce when Bruce tells him how hard he tried to bring Nat back and how much he misses her. Steve says “me too”.

Argh. I’m glad they finalized the repair of Tony and Steve’s friendship because yes, it was an important one too. I also totally get Nat not getting a big funeral the way Tony did (it doesn’t suit her character the way it does his) BUT this moment they could’ve given to her. She was Steve’s friend too, and definitely the one who pushed the hardest for him to find some kind of relationship.

blog.name: damngcoffee
blog.title: My Distractions
blog.description: 30-something spinster fangirl. I blog about: MCU & occasionally other fandoms, ace/aro stuff, spooky things.

summary: Reasons Steve could not have been Peggy’s secret husband all along
title: Reasons Steve could not have been Peggy’s secret husband all along
body:
One day I will stop ranting about this. Not today, apparently.

It goes against the movie’s own explanation of time travel not being able to affect your own past - Nebula shot her past self and it didn’t kill her in 2023. It didn’t erase her life, meaning the two are not connected in any kind of loop. If you change your past without affecting it in your own memory, that means you’ve created an alternate timeline. The only other possibility here is that you can make changes to the past but they ‘don’t count’ so as not to affect your future, but if that were the case, why was anyone worried about messing with time travel at all? And does that mean that 2014 Nebula just pops back into existence after being killed? Make it make sense.

Even if somehow the time loop worked (which it doesn’t, according to the movie’s own barely there internal logic) here are some other issues:

Sharon. Even if CA:CW-time Steve didn’t know who she was, she would have known her own damn relative. She was close enough to Peggy that she would have met her husband. Sharon’s entire existence in the MCU shows that having Steve travel back in time to be with Peggy was never the ultimate plan (especially since they were thinking of putting her in IW, possibly living with Steve). The other option is that Steve lives in a small windowless room and never leaves for 80 years so no one sees his face. What a beautiful life.

Past Steve, stuck in the ice. So we’re supposed to think that Steve steals his own past self’s life to let things play out exactly as they should have? And never tells Peggy? And she’s just cool with young him popping up decades later? (Again, this is if the time loop was a thing, which it isn’t.)

Peggy. Even if Steve does tell Peggy about the other him in the ice, does anyone really think she’d be good with that? That she’d be cool with just letting this future Steve (who lived a third of his life in the 21st century without her, and who she’s lived without for several years) travel back in time to be with her while the Steve she lost a few years ago is buried in the ice? She’s good with just leaving that Steve in the ice? I don’t see a scenario here that would even be remotely likely to happen.

These are all issues I have with this ending completely aside from the fact that, for all intents and purposes, this is a very sad ending for Steve’s character. He’s retreating to a past to which he no longer belongs because he doesn’t feel like the last 12 years of his life have really been worth anything. Fun! So happy he got such a great send off!

And to all those who say ‘can’t he have one nice thing?’ 1. Peggy is not a thing, stop thinking of women that way; she’s not his reward, she has her own life; 2. Abandoning your closest friends to live your life without them is not a ‘nice thing.’ And being selfish =/= not caring about anyone else’s life at all; and 3, Steve’s character is fundamentally about him needing to stand up and do the right thing, and this is not that (and if all he ends up doing in the past is fighting again, well, that’s not really retirement or rest, is it?). You can be selfish, you can retire, and still stand up and do what’s right. But this ending doesn’t accomplish that because he’s running away.
body_abstract: One day I will stop ranting about this. Not today, apparently.

summary:
You know what's more poetic than Tony saying "I am Ironman" then snapping his fingers? Gamora and Nebula stopping Thanos.
There...
body:
You know what’s more poetic than Tony saying “I am Ironman” then snapping his fingers? Gamora and Nebula stopping Thanos.

There was a scene where Gamora told Nebula that they can stop him together. I don’t understand the point of that if they didn’t get to do so.

reblog.comment:

There was a scene where Gamora told Nebula that they can stop him together. I don’t understand the point of that if they didn’t get to do so.

blog.name: itismarvelicious
blog.title: Qu'est-ce que j'irais faire au paradis ?
blog.description: French. 25. | Fixing Avengers: Endgame here. | I take prompts. | Pepperony mainly.

summary:
The Endgame post credit scene they forgot to show us:
Tony, lying down on the couch: and then I woke up. And you know how you...
body:
The Endgame post credit scene they forgot to show us:

Tony, lying down on the couch: and then I woke up. And you know how you feel, when you wake up from a nightmare that seems so real, you’re all sweaty and your heart is pounding in your chest and it feels like you’ve actually lived it -

Bruce: *head falling forward, glasses falling off from his hand*

Tony, turning his head to Bruce, offended: don’t tell me you were napping again. Every time - every time I come to you to get something off my chest -

Bruce: you’ve… Got a baby on your chest.

Tony: yeah, but Morgan needed to sleep - Morgan’s allowed to sleep, I woke her up in the middle of the night because of that nightmare I’ve been telling you about for three hours - three hours.

Bruce: Tony, Thanos’ dead. Thor killed him in Wakanda. The snap never happened. We’re fine. You’re fine. Morgan’s… Throwing up on you.

Tony: It’s fine.

Bruce: Tony, Thanos’ dead. Thor killed him in Wakanda. The snap never happened. We’re fine. You’re fine. Morgan’s… Throwing up on you.

Tony: It’s fine.

blog.description: French. 25. | Fixing Avengers: Endgame here. | I take prompts. | Pepperony mainly.

summary: Basically the MCU broke all the canon ships they ever created. Thor and Jane. Bruce and Nat. Wanda and Vision. Sharon and Steve....
body:
Basically the MCU broke all the canon ships they ever created. Thor and Jane. Bruce and Nat. Wanda and Vision. Sharon and Steve. Pepper and Tony.

I was sad but fine with Thor and Jane being broken up.

I actually personally liked Bruce and Nat but didn’t care whether they’d end up together or not.

Same with Sharon and Steve.

I was a bit heartbroken for Wanda and Vision. Just when I started to really like them, they took them away from us.

I am now however absolutely heartbroken over the death of Tony, therefore the death of my most dearest ship.

Out of all the couples they tried to make, they could’ve at least kept the only one that ever really mattered, the one that lived the longest, the one that made the most sense, the one that was the most real.

The only ones they gave a happy ending to is Steve and Peggy. It’s also personally the only ones I never really cared about - sorry to all the Steggy shippers.

But mostly I wonder what’s the point of making ships if you then don’t know what to make of them or decide to kill them. Just don’t.

I was sad but fine with Thor and Jane being broken up.

I actually personally liked Bruce and Nat but didn’t care whether they’d end up together or not.

Same with Sharon and Steve.

But mostly I wonder what’s the point of making ships if you then don’t know what to make of them or decide to kill them. Just don’t.

summary: I got a little stuck today on how Endgame rewards characters who return to heroism, rather than characters who stay and do the...
caption:
I got a little stuck today on how Endgame rewards characters who return to heroism, rather than characters who stay and do the work, so I mapped it.

The chart is about Avengers, so it doesn’t show everyone’s histories (Okoye’s been in the Dora and Carol’s been working in space for ages; Rocket has been a Guardian for a while), but I think it’s pretty useful.

(In the interests of fairness, I marked off “dust” or “dead” when characters were literally unable to help. Also, I wavered but ultimately didn’t mark Sam off for a Big Hero Moment in Endgame, because even though “on your left” is a HUGE fucking cheer line and Sam deserves it, the scene really didn’t center SAM as a hero, so much as a herald of heroism, and i feel like the big battle scene did not give Sam the kind of moment he deserves for being a stalwart hero.)

summary: My braincells finally fired: Who are the two highest paid original avengers?  Which two characters conveniently died in endgame?...
body:
My braincells finally fired:

  • Who are the two highest paid original avengers?
  • Which two characters conveniently died in endgame?

Like now that i’m looking at that don’t tell me that Marvel “let’s get these unknown actors to sign a 80 picture deal at a laughable rate for the high profile and expected income of these movies so we can take a bigger cut” Studios didn’t specifically target the two original avengers that got signed first and were thereby the most expensive

summary: Even More High-Res Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Images
title: Even More High-Res Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Images
body:
Even More High-Res #AvengersEndgame Spoiler Images

Last week Marvel released several high-res images from the end of Avengers: Endgame, and now they’ve released nine more.

The images include the “A-Force” scene, as well as that amazing shot of the entire MCU charging at Thanos and his army.

summary: Avengers Endgame: Male Entitlement Undermines Steve Rogers' Core Characterization and Story Arc - Cinemalogue
title: Avengers Endgame: Male Entitlement Undermines Steve Rogers' Core Characterization and Story Arc - Cinemalogue
excerpt: In my previous editorial, I explored transformative fandom’s movement to embrace Steve Rogers as not only a champion of the LGBT community, but as a member of that marginalized demographic. From his creation as a stalwart anti-Fascist hero to his present incarnation, Rogers represents the tireless drive to do right, no matter the cost. A man of …
description: This article is a pitch perfect criticism of a number of the problems with Steve’s ending and his whole characterization in Endgame. I love how many articles like this have come out; each time a new one does I feel a little less destroyed by his ending, because it’s clear the writers and directors did not think this through and that people are noticing.

I love how many articles like this have come out; each time a new one does I feel a little less destroyed by his ending, because it’s clear the writers and directors did not think this through and that people are noticing.

summary: Sorry, Captain Marvel, But Thanos Is the MCU's Strongest Character
title: Sorry, Captain Marvel, But Thanos Is the MCU's Strongest Character
excerpt: Avengers: Endgame made it clear: The most powerful character in the Marvel Cinematic Universe isn't Captain Marvel -- it's Thanos.
description:
…How does him using his ships to blow up the Scarlet Witch when she’s telekinetically beginning to pull him apart like fresh bread, or him having to resort to ejecting the Power Stone to zap Carol when she’s beginning to overpower him make him the “Strongest Character“?

Seems kind of Rules Lawyerish. Like the people who include enhanced characters like Deathstroke (has drugs which make him evil eyepatch-wearing Captain America) and Prometheus (downloads martial arts moves into his brain like Neo so he can fight people on autopilot) on lists of DC’s greatest martial artists despite them clearly cheating, just so female characters like Lady Shiva or Cassandra Cain won’t have the top spots.

summary: What if: Thanos hired a Skrull in Infinity War. In any opportunity, they should imitate an Avenger and be a spy for him. He...
body: What if: Thanos hired a Skrull in Infinity War. In any opportunity, they should imitate an Avenger and be a spy for him. He became Steve Rogers when the opportunity arose (Steve was killed in the Snap, maybe). He didn’t want to be Thanos’s spy, so instead he helped to defeat Thanos. He needed a way to get out of the original Steve’s way and the others’ after killing Thanos, so he decided to go back in time to escape. The impostor told Sam and Bucky after giving Sam the shield about their new mission: finding the real Steve Rogers.
